symptom: Cannot access the internet from a workstation
conditions: Ping to 8.8.8.8 (Google DNS) fails
Ping to the default gateway (router IP) fails
Network interface status shows 'DOWN' or 'NO-CARRIER' (`ip link show`)
diagnosis: Local network issue, cable disconnection, or network interface is down
solution: Check physical Ethernet cable connection to the workstation and network device (switch/router)
Ensure the network interface card (NIC) is enabled and up (`ip link set eth0 up` or similar)
Verify the link lights on the NIC and the switch/router port are lit and steady/blinking
Check for driver issues for the network adapter (e.g., `dmesg | grep -i eth` for errors)
Try connecting the workstation to a different port on the network switch/router
Reboot the workstation

symptom: Workstation has 'Limited or No Connectivity' / APIPA address (169.254.x.x)
conditions: Workstation's IP address is in the 169.254.0.0/16 range (`ip a` or `ipconfig /all`)
Cannot ping the default gateway
DHCP client service is running on the workstation
diagnosis: DHCP server not reachable, no DHCP lease, or IP address conflict
solution: Renew DHCP lease (`dhclient -r && dhclient` or `ipconfig /release && ipconfig /renew`)
Verify the DHCP server is operational and reachable on the network
Check for any IP address conflicts using `arp -a` or network scanner tools
Ensure no MAC address filtering is enabled on the router/switch that would block the workstation
Restart the NetworkManager or networking service on the workstation
Temporarily assign a static IP address to test basic network connectivity

symptom: Intermittent network connection drops on a wired connection
conditions: Ping tests show packet loss and high latency sporadically
Network link lights flicker erratically on the NIC or switch port
Errors reported in `dmesg` or `ip -s link show eth0` (e.g., 'rx_errors', 'tx_errors')
diagnosis: Faulty Ethernet cable, loose connection, or failing network adapter/port
solution: Replace the Ethernet cable with a known good one
Try a different port on the network switch/router
Reseat the network adapter card in the workstation's PCI slot (if applicable)
Update or reinstall the network adapter drivers
Check for electromagnetic interference (EMI) sources near the cable run
Inspect the cable and connectors for physical damage

symptom: Cannot access specific internal server by IP address or hostname
conditions: Ping to the server's IP address fails
Other devices on the same subnet can access the server
Firewall on the client workstation is temporarily disabled for testing
diagnosis: Incorrect subnet configuration, VLAN mismatch, or routing issue
solution: Verify the workstation's IP address, subnet mask, and default gateway (`ip a`, `ip route`)
Check the server's IP configuration to ensure it's on the expected subnet
Examine the routing table on the workstation (`ip route show`) for specific routes to the server's network
Confirm there are no VLAN mismatches on the switch ports connecting the workstation and the server
Perform a `traceroute` or `tracert` to the server to identify where connectivity breaks down
Check switch port configuration (e.g., VLAN assignments, port security) for the server and client

symptom: Wireless network connection is unstable or drops frequently
conditions: Signal strength is reported as low or fluctuating by the wireless adapter
Packet loss observed during continuous ping tests to the wireless router
Other wireless devices experience similar issues on the same network
diagnosis: Poor signal strength, interference, or faulty wireless access point/router
solution: Relocate the wireless router/access point to a more central location or closer to the devices
Change the wireless channel on the router to avoid interference from neighboring networks (`iwlist scan` to identify occupied channels)
Update the firmware of the wireless router/access point
Update or reinstall the wireless adapter drivers on the affected devices
Check for physical obstructions (walls, metal objects) that might block the signal
Consider upgrading to a newer wireless standard (e.g., Wi-Fi 6) or adding more access points for better coverage

symptom: Newly added device cannot connect to the network (wired)
conditions: Device does not obtain an IP address via DHCP or configured static IP does not work
Link light on the switch port or device NIC is off or flashes intermittently
No MAC address entry for the device is seen in the switch's MAC address table (`show mac address-table`)
diagnosis: Faulty cable, incorrect switch port configuration, or dead network adapter on the new device
solution: Verify the Ethernet cable is functional and correctly connected on both ends
Try a different port on the network switch that is known to be operational
Check the switch port configuration (e.g., port status, VLAN assignment, port security) to ensure it's active and correct
Inspect the network adapter on the new device for physical damage or signs of failure
Ensure the new device's network adapter drivers are installed and up to date (if applicable)
If using static IP, double-check the IP, subnet mask, and gateway configuration on the new device

symptom: Cannot access network shares on a Windows server
conditions: Ping to the Windows server's IP address is successful
Server can access other network resources
Error message 'Network path not found' or 'Access Denied'
diagnosis: Firewall blocking SMB/CIFS ports, incorrect share permissions, or server service issues
solution: Verify the server's firewall (Windows Firewall or third-party) is not blocking SMB ports (445, 139)
Check the share permissions on the Windows server to ensure the user has appropriate access
Ensure the 'Server' and 'Workstation' services are running on the Windows server
Verify that network discovery and file sharing are enabled on the server's network profile
Attempt to access the share using the server's IP address instead of hostname (e.g., `\\192.168.1.100\sharename`)
Check event logs on the server for errors related to SMB or authentication

symptom: Multiple users report slow network access to a specific server application
conditions: Ping latency to the server is consistently high from multiple clients
Server's CPU or memory utilization is reported as high
`netstat -an | grep :<app_port>` shows many connections in `TIME_WAIT` or `CLOSE_WAIT` state
diagnosis: Server overload, network congestion, or application-specific issues
solution: Monitor the server's resource utilization (CPU, RAM, disk I/O) to check for bottlenecks
Use `iperf` or `nuttcp` to test network bandwidth between clients and the server
Examine network device (switch, router) logs for interface errors or high utilization on ports connected to the server
Review the application's logs for performance warnings or errors
Optimize the application configuration or database queries if it's application-bound
Consider upgrading server hardware or scaling out the application infrastructure

symptom: Guest Wi-Fi network is not broadcasting or clients cannot connect
conditions: SSID for guest network is not visible in wireless scans
Clients receive authentication errors when attempting to connect to the guest SSID
WLAN controller or access point logs show errors related to guest network provisioning
diagnosis: Guest network disabled, incorrect security settings, or VLAN/routing misconfiguration
solution: Verify that the guest Wi-Fi network is enabled and configured correctly on the access point/controller
Double-check the security settings (SSID, password, authentication method) for the guest network
Ensure the VLAN assigned to the guest network is correctly tagged on switch ports and routed on the firewall/router
Check DHCP scope for the guest network to ensure IP addresses are being assigned
Restart the access point(s) or wireless controller
Review the firewall rules that might be blocking DHCP or DNS traffic for the guest network

symptom: Devices in one VLAN cannot communicate with devices in another VLAN
conditions: Ping fails between devices in different VLANs, but succeeds within the same VLAN
Router's interface for inter-VLAN routing shows 'DOWN' or incorrect IP configuration
Switch port modes (access/trunk) and native VLAN settings are mismatched
diagnosis: Inter-VLAN routing misconfiguration, VLAN tagging issues, or firewall rules blocking traffic
solution: Verify the router's sub-interfaces or routed interfaces are configured correctly with the appropriate VLAN IDs and IP addresses
Ensure switch ports connecting to the router are configured as trunk ports and allowing the necessary VLANs
Check that devices in each VLAN have the correct default gateway configured (the router's IP for their VLAN)
Examine firewall rules on the router or firewall appliance that might be blocking inter-VLAN traffic
Use `traceroute` to identify where the traffic is being dropped between VLANs
Review `show interface trunk` and `show vlan` commands on switches for correct VLAN assignments

symptom: Specific web application not loading or showing 'Connection Refused' error
conditions: Ping to the web server is successful
Access to other applications or services on the same server works
Browser shows specific error messages like 'Connection Refused' or 'ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED'
diagnosis: Application not running, web server misconfiguration, or application-level firewalling
solution: Verify the web application service (e.g., Apache, Nginx, IIS) is running on the server
Check the web server configuration files for correct port listening and virtual host settings
Examine any application-level firewalls or security groups on the server that might be blocking access to the application's port
Inspect the web server access and error logs for specific application errors
Use `telnet <server_ip> <app_port>` to test if the port is open and listening
Restart the web application service or the entire web server

symptom: New router installed, but devices cannot get internet access
conditions: Devices obtain IP addresses from the new router's DHCP server
Ping to the router's IP address is successful, but ping to external IPs (e.g., 8.8.8.8) fails
Router's WAN interface status shows 'Disconnected' or no IP from ISP
diagnosis: WAN connection issue, ISP configuration, or router's NAT/routing misconfiguration
solution: Verify the WAN cable is securely connected to the router and the ISP modem/ONT
Power cycle the ISP modem/ONT and then the new router
Check the router's WAN configuration for correct connection type (DHCP, PPPoE, Static IP) and credentials (if applicable)
Confirm that the router's internal routing table and NAT settings are correctly configured
Contact the ISP to verify their service is active and there are no issues on their end
Check the router's firewall settings to ensure it's not blocking outbound internet access

symptom: Remote users cannot access internal resources via site-to-site VPN
conditions: VPN tunnel status on both ends shows 'UP' or 'Connected'
Ping from remote network to internal network devices fails
Traffic logs on the firewall/router show packets being dropped or denied over the VPN tunnel
diagnosis: Incorrect VPN routing, firewall rules, or mismatched encryption settings
solution: Verify that the correct interesting traffic (networks to be tunneled) is defined on both VPN endpoints
Check routing tables on both VPN endpoints to ensure routes exist for the remote network through the tunnel interface
Examine firewall rules on both ends to ensure traffic is permitted to pass through the VPN tunnel
Confirm that VPN encryption, authentication, and phase 1/2 settings match exactly on both endpoints
Review VPN logs for specific errors or reasons for traffic drops
Perform a packet capture on both ends of the VPN tunnel to see if traffic is entering and exiting as expected

symptom: VoIP phones are not registering or making calls
conditions: VoIP phone displays 'Registering' or 'Network Error'
No IP address obtained by the phone or incorrect VLAN assigned
SIP server or call manager cannot be reached by the phone (`ping <sip_server_ip>` fails)
diagnosis: Network connectivity issues, VLAN misconfiguration, or missing VoIP QoS settings
solution: Verify network connectivity from the phone to the SIP server/call manager (ping, traceroute)
Ensure the correct VLAN is assigned to the switch port connected to the VoIP phone (if using voice VLANs)
Check DHCP scope options (e.g., Option 66 for TFTP server) are correctly configured for VoIP phones
Ensure QoS (Quality of Service) is enabled and configured on switches and routers to prioritize VoIP traffic
Verify that firewall rules are not blocking SIP (UDP 5060) or RTP (UDP 10000-20000) ports
Restart the VoIP phone and check its configuration for correct server IP and credentials

symptom: Remote desktop (RDP) connections fail to a server
conditions: Ping to the server is successful, but RDP connection attempts time out or fail
Server is listening on RDP port (3389) according to `netstat -an | grep 3389` on the server
Other services on the server are accessible (e.g., ping, HTTP)
diagnosis: Server's firewall blocking RDP, RDP service not running, or network access control lists (ACLs)
solution: Check the Windows Firewall or third-party firewall on the server to ensure RDP port 3389 is allowed for inbound connections
Verify that the Remote Desktop Services service is running on the server
Ensure that users attempting to connect are part of the 'Remote Desktop Users' group on the server
Check network access control lists (ACLs) on routers or switches in the path that might be blocking RDP traffic
Attempt to connect from a different client or network segment to isolate the issue
Review the server's event logs for RDP-related errors or security events

symptom: Network printer is offline or inaccessible from workstations
conditions: Ping to the printer's IP address fails from client workstations
Printer's control panel shows 'Offline' or 'Network Error'
Other network devices on the same subnet as the printer are accessible
diagnosis: Printer network configuration issue, faulty cable, or network connectivity loss to the printer
solution: Power cycle the printer and allow it to re-acquire an IP address (if DHCP)
Verify the Ethernet cable is securely connected to the printer and the network switch
Check the printer's network settings (IP address, subnet mask, default gateway) via its control panel or web interface
Ensure the switch port connected to the printer is active and configured correctly (e.g., same VLAN as workstations)
If a print server is used, verify the print server is online and its services are running
Try assigning a static IP address to the printer to rule out DHCP issues

symptom: Client device cannot reach default gateway after reboot
conditions: Workstation's IP address is correct but `ping <default_gateway_ip>` fails
ARP cache on the workstation does not show the gateway's MAC address (`arp -a`)
Switch port connected to the workstation is active, but no traffic is passing
diagnosis: ARP cache issue, faulty switch port, or gateway device issue
solution: Clear the ARP cache on the workstation (`arp -d *` on Windows, `ip -s -s neigh flush all` on Linux)
Try a different switch port for the workstation's connection
Power cycle the default gateway (router/Layer 3 switch)
Verify the default gateway device is operational and its interface connecting to the workstation's subnet is up
Check for duplicate IP addresses on the network for the default gateway IP
Perform a packet capture on the workstation to see if ARP requests for the gateway are being sent and replied to

symptom: Internet access is working, but some websites are unreachable or slow to load
conditions: Ping to 8.8.8.8 is successful, but `ping <unreachable_website>` fails or times out
`traceroute` to the unreachable website times out at a specific hop outside the local network
DNS resolution for the website is successful (`nslookup <website>`), but connection to the IP fails
diagnosis: ISP routing issue, specific website server issue, or external firewall blocking
solution: Test connectivity to other external websites to confirm it's not a general internet outage
Use `traceroute` to the problematic website to identify where the connection breaks down (often indicates ISP issue or destination server issue)
Check the status of the problematic website using online tools (e.g., 'Is It Down Right Now?')
Clear browser cache and DNS cache on the client workstation
Temporarily change DNS servers to public ones (e.g., 8.8.8.8, 1.1.1.1) to rule out DNS issues
Contact your ISP if `traceroute` indicates issues on their network

symptom: Network Time Protocol (NTP) synchronization fails for network devices
conditions: Devices show incorrect time or time drift when compared to a known accurate source
`ntpq -p` or `ntpstat` on Linux devices show 'unreachable' or 'no server' status
Firewall logs indicate traffic to NTP port (UDP 123) is being blocked
diagnosis: NTP server not reachable, firewall blocking NTP, or incorrect NTP server configuration
solution: Verify the NTP server IP address and connectivity (`ping <ntp_server_ip>`)
Ensure firewall rules allow outbound UDP port 123 traffic from devices to the NTP server and inbound replies
Check the NTP server daemon status (e.g., `systemctl status ntp` or `chronyd`) on the server itself
Ensure the NTP client configuration on network devices points to the correct NTP server(s)
If using internal NTP server, verify it's synchronizing correctly with external sources
Restart the NTP client service on the affected devices

symptom: New network segment (subnet) cannot reach existing network segments
conditions: Devices in the new segment can communicate within their own segment but not across to old segments
Routing table on the main router or Layer 3 switch does not show routes to the new segment
ACLs or firewall rules on the router are not updated to permit traffic between segments
diagnosis: Missing routing configuration, incorrect subnet mask, or unconfigured firewall rules
solution: Add static routes to the main router or Layer 3 switch for the new network segment, pointing to its gateway
If using dynamic routing protocols (OSPF, EIGRP), ensure the new segment is advertised or redistributed correctly
Verify that the subnet mask and network addresses are correctly configured on all interfaces and routing entries
Update any firewall rules or ACLs on the router to allow traffic flow between the new and existing segments
Perform a `traceroute` from a device in the new segment to a device in an old segment to pinpoint the routing failure
Check for any overlapping IP address ranges between the new and existing segments
